channel.title: News : NPR
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2018 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Major Psychiatric Disorders Have More In Common Than We Thought, Study Finds
item.description: Understanding the molecular basis of major disorders such as autism, schizophrenia and bipolar is hopeful, because it could help in developing better treatments for them.
item.content:encoded:
Understanding the molecular basis of major disorders such as autism, schizophrenia and bipolar is hopeful, because it could help in developing better treatments for them.

(Image credit: Sebastian Kaulitzki/Getty Images/Science Photo Library RF)
item.dc:creator: Merrit Kennedy

item.title: After Rob Porter Resigns, Former WH Secretary Lisa Brown Discusses Position's Importance
item.description: White House staff secretary Rob Porter has resigned after accusations that he abused his ex-wives. NPR's Ari Shapiro speaks with former staff secretary Lisa Brown about the importance of the job in a presidential administration.
item.content:encoded: White House staff secretary Rob Porter has resigned after accusations that he abused his ex-wives. NPR's Ari Shapiro speaks with former staff secretary Lisa Brown about the importance of the job in a presidential administration.

item.title: Champion Of The Internet And Grateful Dead Lyricist John Perry Barlow Dies At 70
item.description: John Perry Barlow has died at 70. Barlow was the co-founder of the digital rights group Electronic Frontier Foundation. He was also a lyricist for the Grateful Dead.
item.content:encoded: John Perry Barlow has died at 70. Barlow was the co-founder of the digital rights group Electronic Frontier Foundation. He was also a lyricist for the Grateful Dead.
item.dc:creator: Rachael Myrow

item.title: Comparing Republican And Democratic Theories About The 2018 Midterm Elections
item.description: Positive attitudes about the economy have been making the GOP more optimistic that they can limit losses in the midterm elections. But market volatility this week showed that to be a risky proposition.
item.content:encoded: Positive attitudes about the economy have been making the GOP more optimistic that they can limit losses in the midterm elections. But market volatility this week showed that to be a risky proposition.
item.dc:creator: Mara Liasson

item.title: White House Is Reviewing Democratic Memo That Responds To GOP Allegations
item.description: The White House is reviewing a Democratic memo that responds to Republicans allegations of purported FBI abuses of surveillance powers.
item.content:encoded: The White House is reviewing a Democratic memo that responds to Republicans allegations of purported FBI abuses of surveillance powers.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Lucas

item.title: Putin's Most Prominent Opponent Says There's No Doubt Kremlin Interfered In 2016 Election
item.description: The leading opposition politician in Russia says he doesn't have the slightest doubt that the Kremlin interfered in the 2016 U.S. presidential election.
item.content:encoded: The leading opposition politician in Russia says he doesn't have the slightest doubt that the Kremlin interfered in the 2016 U.S. presidential election.
item.dc:creator: Lucian Kim

item.title: Chief Of Staff John Kelly Faces Questions On Immigration Comments, Handling Of Staff
item.description: White House Chief of Staff John Kelly is facing questions about his handling of abuse allegations against a senior White House staffer, but this is not the first time Kelly has come under fire.
item.content:encoded: White House Chief of Staff John Kelly is facing questions about his handling of abuse allegations against a senior White House staffer, but this is not the first time Kelly has come under fire.
item.dc:creator: Tamara Keith

item.title: North Korea Holds Military Parade, Shows Off Weapons Ahead Of Olympic Opening
item.description: On the eve of the opening ceremony for the Pyeongchang Winter Olympics in South Korea, North Korea staged a giant military parade in its capital. Its showing of military force might justify its playing nice in the South, where a joint North-South orchestra performed together in one of the cities hosting the games.
item.content:encoded: On the eve of the opening ceremony for the Pyeongchang Winter Olympics in South Korea, North Korea staged a giant military parade in its capital. Its showing of military force might justify its playing nice in the South, where a joint North-South orchestra performed together in one of the cities hosting the games.
item.dc:creator: Elise Hu

item.title: How The Launch Of SpaceX's Falcon Heavy Fits Into The Company's Other-Wordly Plans
item.description: This week SpaceX successfully launched the world's most powerful rocket in decades. NPR's Ari Shapiro speaks with writer Tim Urban about what this rocket will do near term, and how it takes Elon Musk one step closer to his grand vision of a million-person colony on Mars.
item.content:encoded: This week SpaceX successfully launched the world's most powerful rocket in decades. NPR's Ari Shapiro speaks with writer Tim Urban about what this rocket will do near term, and how it takes Elon Musk one step closer to his grand vision of a million-person colony on Mars.

item.title: FBI Says They Have No Evidence That Border Patrol Agent's Death Was A Homicide
item.description: There has been a big development in the mysterious death of a Border Patrol agent beside a remote highway in West Texas last year. The case received national attention because President Trump speculated it was a brutal murder committed by smugglers. The FBI now says, after an exhaustive investigation, that they have found no evidence the officer's death was a homicide.
item.content:encoded: There has been a big development in the mysterious death of a Border Patrol agent beside a remote highway in West Texas last year. The case received national attention because President Trump speculated it was a brutal murder committed by smugglers. The FBI now says, after an exhaustive investigation, that they have found no evidence the officer's death was a homicide.
item.dc:creator: John Burnett

item.title: Pentagon Audit Shows Logistical Arm Of Military Can't Explain Where $800 Million Went
item.description: NPR's Mary Louise Kelly talks with Politico's Bryan Bender about a story he broke earlier this week on troubling results from an internal audit at the Pentagon. The audit finds that the Defense Logistics Agency has no paper trail for more than $800 million in construction projects.
item.content:encoded: NPR's Mary Louise Kelly talks with Politico's Bryan Bender about a story he broke earlier this week on troubling results from an internal audit at the Pentagon. The audit finds that the Defense Logistics Agency has no paper trail for more than $800 million in construction projects.

item.title: Eagles Continue To Fly And Soar As Philadelphians Celebrate Super Bowl Win
item.description: Philadelphians lined a parade route through the city's downtown, hoping to catch a glimpse of their beloved Eagles. Some businesses closed and kids had the day off from school, all to celebrate the team's Super Bowl win over the New England Patriots.
item.content:encoded: Philadelphians lined a parade route through the city's downtown, hoping to catch a glimpse of their beloved Eagles. Some businesses closed and kids had the day off from school, all to celebrate the team's Super Bowl win over the New England Patriots.
item.dc:creator: Bobby Allyn

item.title: Republican Rep. Mo Brooks Says Americans Can't Afford Latest Spending Bill
item.description: NPR's Ari Shapiro talks with Rep. Mo Brooks, R-Ala., a member of the House Freedom Caucus, about the spending bill currently in front of Congress that would increase spending and add to the national deficit.
item.content:encoded: NPR's Ari Shapiro talks with Rep. Mo Brooks, R-Ala., a member of the House Freedom Caucus, about the spending bill currently in front of Congress that would increase spending and add to the national deficit.

item.title: Democratic Rep. Joe Crowley Says He Won't Vote For Senate Spending Proposal
item.description: NPR's Mary Louise Kelly speaks with Congressman Joe Crowley of New York, who is chair of the Democratic Caucus, about the Senate budget deal which doesn't include anything on immigration, and what it would mean for House Democrats.
item.content:encoded: NPR's Mary Louise Kelly speaks with Congressman Joe Crowley of New York, who is chair of the Democratic Caucus, about the Senate budget deal which doesn't include anything on immigration, and what it would mean for House Democrats.

item.title: A Young Rohingya Mom: Pregnant, Stateless, Living In Limbo
item.description: Sanura Begum fled Myanmar and now lives in the world's largest refugee camp in Bangladesh. Could she ever return to the wooden farmhouse she left behind? Only God knows, she says.
item.content:encoded:
Sanura Begum fled Myanmar and now lives in the world's largest refugee camp in Bangladesh. Could she ever return to the wooden farmhouse she left behind? Only God knows, she says.

(Image credit: Allison Joyce for NPR)
item.dc:creator: Jason Beaubien
